trans-unit.source: Capture an image of a virtual machine running Linux
trans-unit.target: Capture an image of a virtual machine running Linux

trans-unit.source: Learn how to capture an image of an Azure virtual machine (VM) running Linux.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to capture an image of an Azure virtual machine (VM) running Linux.

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to capture an Azure virtual machine running Linux so you can use it like a template to create other virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to capture an Azure virtual machine running Linux so you can use it like a template to create other virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: This template includes the OS disk and data disks attached to the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This template includes the OS disk and data disks attached to the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: It doesn't include networking configuration, so you'll need to configure that when you create the other virtual machines that use the template.
trans-unit.target: It doesn't include networking configuration, so you'll need to configure that when you create the other virtual machines that use the template.

trans-unit.source: Azure treats this template as an image and stores it under Images.
trans-unit.target: Azure treats this template as an image and stores it under Images.

trans-unit.source: This is also where any images you've uploaded are stored.
trans-unit.target: This is also where any images you've uploaded are stored.

trans-unit.source: For more information about images, see <linkText>About Virtual Machine Images in Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about images, see <linkText>About Virtual Machine Images in Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: These steps assume that you've already created an Azure virtual machine using the classic deployment model and configured the operating system, including attaching any data disks.
trans-unit.target: These steps assume that you've already created an Azure virtual machine using the classic deployment model and configured the operating system, including attaching any data disks.

trans-unit.source: If you haven't done this yet, see these instructions:
trans-unit.target: If you haven't done this yet, see these instructions:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>How to Create a Virtual Machine Running Linux</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>How to Create a Virtual Machine Running Linux</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Connect to the virtual machine using an SSH client of your choice.
trans-unit.target: Connect to the virtual machine using an SSH client of your choice.

trans-unit.source: For details, see <linkText>How to Log on to a Virtual Machine Running Linux</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For details, see <linkText>How to Log on to a Virtual Machine Running Linux</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the SSH window, type the following command.
trans-unit.target: In the SSH window, type the following command.

trans-unit.source: Note that the output from waagent may vary slightly depending on the version of this utility:
trans-unit.target: Note that the output from waagent may vary slightly depending on the version of this utility:

trans-unit.source: sudo waagent -deprovision
trans-unit.target: sudo waagent -deprovision

trans-unit.source: This command will attempt to clean the system and make it suitable for re-provisioning.
trans-unit.target: This command will attempt to clean the system and make it suitable for re-provisioning.

trans-unit.source: This operation performs the following tasks:
trans-unit.target: This operation performs the following tasks:

trans-unit.source: Removes SSH host keys (if Provisioning.RegenerateSshHostKeyPair is 'y' in the configuration file)
trans-unit.target: Removes SSH host keys (if Provisioning.RegenerateSshHostKeyPair is 'y' in the configuration file)

trans-unit.source: Clears nameserver configuration in /etc/resolv.conf
trans-unit.target: Clears nameserver configuration in /etc/resolv.conf

trans-unit.source: Removes the root user's password from /etc/shadow (if Provisioning.DeleteRootPassword is 'y' in the configuration file)
trans-unit.target: Removes the root user's password from /etc/shadow (if Provisioning.DeleteRootPassword is 'y' in the configuration file)

trans-unit.source: Removes cached DHCP client leases
trans-unit.target: Removes cached DHCP client leases

trans-unit.source: Resets host name to localhost.localdomain
trans-unit.target: Resets host name to localhost.localdomain

trans-unit.source: Deletes the last provisioned user account (obtained from /var/lib/waagent) and associated data.
trans-unit.target: Deletes the last provisioned user account (obtained from /var/lib/waagent) and associated data.

trans-unit.source: Deprovisioning deletes files and data in an effort to "generalize" the image.
trans-unit.target: Deprovisioning deletes files and data in an effort to "generalize" the image.

trans-unit.source: Only run this command on virtual machines that you intend to capture as a new image template.
trans-unit.target: Only run this command on virtual machines that you intend to capture as a new image template.

trans-unit.source: It does not guarantee that the image is cleared of all sensitive information or is suitable for redistribution to third parties.
trans-unit.target: It does not guarantee that the image is cleared of all sensitive information or is suitable for redistribution to third parties.

trans-unit.source: Type y to continue.
trans-unit.target: Type y to continue.

trans-unit.source: You can add the -force parameter to avoid this confirmation step.
trans-unit.target: You can add the -force parameter to avoid this confirmation step.

trans-unit.source: Type Exit to close the SSH client.
trans-unit.target: Type Exit to close the SSH client.

trans-unit.source: The next steps assume you have already <linkText>installed the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title> on your client computer.
trans-unit.target: The next steps assume you have already <linkText>installed the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title> on your client computer.

trans-unit.source: All the steps below can also be done in the <linkText>Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: All the steps below can also be done in the <linkText>Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: From your client computer, open Azure CLI and login to your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: From your client computer, open Azure CLI and login to your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: For details, read <linkText>Connect to an Azure subscription from the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For details, read <linkText>Connect to an Azure subscription from the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you are in Service Management mode:
trans-unit.target: Make sure you are in Service Management mode:

trans-unit.source: azure config mode asm
trans-unit.target: azure config mode asm

trans-unit.source: Shut down the virtual machine which is already deprovisioned in the steps above with:
trans-unit.target: Shut down the virtual machine which is already deprovisioned in the steps above with:

trans-unit.source: azure vm shutdown
trans-unit.target: azure vm shutdown

trans-unit.source: You can find out all the virtual machines created in your subscription by using azure vm list
trans-unit.target: You can find out all the virtual machines created in your subscription by using azure vm list

trans-unit.source: When the virtual machine is stopped, capture the image with the command:
trans-unit.target: When the virtual machine is stopped, capture the image with the command:

trans-unit.source: azure vm capture -t
trans-unit.target: azure vm capture -t

trans-unit.source: Type the image name you want in place of new-image-name.
trans-unit.target: Type the image name you want in place of new-image-name.

trans-unit.source: This command creates a generalized OS image.
trans-unit.target: This command creates a generalized OS image.

trans-unit.source: The -t subcommand deletes the original virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: The -t subcommand deletes the original virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The new image is now available in the list of images that can be used to configure any new virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: The new image is now available in the list of images that can be used to configure any new virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: You can view it with the command:
trans-unit.target: You can view it with the command:

trans-unit.source: azure vm image list
trans-unit.target: azure vm image list

trans-unit.source: On the Management Portal, it will appear in the IMAGES list.
trans-unit.target: On the Management Portal, it will appear in the IMAGES list.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Image capture successful</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Image capture successful</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The image is ready to be used as a template to create virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: The image is ready to be used as a template to create virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: You can use the Azure CLI command azure vm create and supply the image name you just created.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Azure CLI command azure vm create and supply the image name you just created.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Using Azure CLI with the Service Management API</linkText><title></title> for details about the command.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Using Azure CLI with the Service Management API</linkText><title></title> for details about the command.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can use the Management Portal to create a custom virtual machine by using the From Gallery method and selecting the image you just created.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can use the Management Portal to create a custom virtual machine by using the From Gallery method and selecting the image you just created.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>How to Create a Custom Virtual Machine</linkText><title></title> for more details.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>How to Create a Custom Virtual Machine</linkText><title></title> for more details.

trans-unit.source: See Also: Azure Linux Agent User Guide
trans-unit.target: See Also: Azure Linux Agent User Guide

trans-unit.source: http://manage.windowsazure.com
trans-unit.target: http://manage.windowsazure.com

trans-unit.target: virtual-machines-linux-how-to-log-on.md

trans-unit.target: http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn790290.aspx

trans-unit.target: virtual-machines-create-custom.md

trans-unit.target: storage-windows-attach-disk.md

trans-unit.target: virtual-machines-linux-tutorial.md
